title-group.article-title: Tip tracking control of a micro-cantilever Timoshenko beam via piezoelectric actuator

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, Sharif University of Technology, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Hassan Salarieh, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Sharif University of Technology, PO Box 11155–9567, Tehran, Iran Email: salarieh@sharif.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this paper, the tip tracking control problem of a Timoshenko micro-cantilever beam is investigated. The beam is actuated by a piezoelectric layer laminated on one side of the beam. Dynamic equations of the beam and piezoelectric layer are found using the Hamilton principle. By employing the Galerkin projection method, state space representation of the system is derived. Then, a cascade control loop is used for tracking control of the beam’s tip. The cascade control structure consists of an inner loop stabilizer and an outer loop proportional-integral-derivative controller. The stabilizer has a linear feedback form whose states are obtained through a linear observer which is based on the beam tip displacement measurement. Stability analysis of the inner loop stabilizer is performed to study the effects of higher un-controlled modes on performance of the controlled system. Simulation results show the effectiveness of the proposed control method.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Nowadays, micro-electro-mechanical systems (MEMS) play a crucial role in science and technology. There are many applications for MEMS. Micro-pumps which are utilized for drug delivery (Bourouinay et al., 1997; Maillefer et al., 1999, 2001; Nguyen et al., 2008; Nisar et al., 2008) are just one of the important applications of MEMS. Another important micro-system is the micro-beam. Since there are many problems in fabricating joints in micro-scales, micro-systems motion is usually achieved due to the elasticity of materials and their deflection. Therefore, in design, analysis, and control of micro-systems, solving the equations of elasticity is inevitable. Due to its simple equations of motion, the micro-beam has found a very important position among micro-systems. There are many applications for micro-beams. Atomic force microscopy (AFM), which is used to inspect the surface of materials, can be considered as a famous example. A review on researches conducted on AFM can be found in the work of Jalili and Laxminarayana (2004). Micro-switch is another application of micro-beams that is used for high frequency switching (Suzuki and Neav, 2003; Coutu et al., 2004; Vummidi et al., 2009; Mohammadi-Alasti et al., 2010).Other famous applications are micro mirrors (Tuantranont et al., 2000; Youngjoo et al., 2000; Kim et al., 2010) and grating light valves (Perry, 2004; Florin et al., 2010; Rudra et al., 2010).

Two major types of actuators are usually applied to control micro-beams. One of them is the electrostatic actuator which is based on the attraction force between two plates at different voltage levels (Choi and Lovell, 1997; Chen and Ou, 2007). The other one is the piezoelectric actuator. Piezoelectric actuators are usually laminated on the beam during the fabrication process. Applying electric voltage to the piezoelectric layer can cause strain due to piezoelectricity, and this strain can deflect the micro-beam (Zhang et al., 2006). Compared to piezoelectric actuators, electrostatic actuators are easier to fabricate, but noting that they work based on attraction, they cannot produce a repulsive force. As a result, positioning and tracking control with electrostatic actuators seems more difficult than employing piezoelectric actuators.

A lot of research has been conducted into the control of micro-beams. One important problem is vibration control, in which the aim of the controller is to suppress the vibration of a beam under excitation. In the work of Zhang et al. (2006) a controller based on a high gain observer is applied to control the vibration of an Euler-Bernoulli micro-beam employing a piezoelectric actuator, especially in resonance frequencies. However, the effects of coupling between different modes due to the existence of a piezoelectric layer are neglected. Sadek et al. (2009) considered the vibration control of an Euler-Bernoulli beam via a boundary control algorithm with minimum control effort. Another important problem associated with control of beams is the regulation control of the beam, which is considered in the work of Fard and Sagatun (2001) for an Euler Bernoulli beam via boundary control. The aim of regulation control is to stabilize the deflection of the tip or the whole body of the beam, when it is under the effect of a destabilizing force. Krstic et al. (2008) designed a controller based on the boundary backstepping method to stabilize a shear cantilever beam with a destabilizing force acting on its tip by measuring the tip deflection and the tip angle due to bending.

The goal in tip tracking control of a cantilever is to make the tip of beam follow a desired signal. Tip tracking control of a cantilever micro-beam is important in nano-manipulating and it is applied in micro-robotics (Xu et al., 2000). In addition, it can be interesting in the design of a high frequency switch. The important point is that in MEMS, an infinite dimensional system is being dealt with, with very restricted measurement data due to the restriction in using sensors in a real setup. Therefore, the design of a control law without using an observer is not feasible.

Micro-systems have a relatively high bandwidth, which is one of the most important advantages of these systems. Since the bandwidth of mechanical parts is usually lower than the electrical parts, the speed of micro-systems can be improved by employing faster mechanical parts. To this end, thicker and stiffer beams, which have higher natural frequencies, can be applied. To model a thick beam with high frequency excitation, as usually occurs in micro systems, the Timoshenko theory of beam must be employed (Han et al., 1999).

In this paper, a thick micro-cantilever beam actuating with a piezoelectric layer is considered. The beam is modeled by the Timoshenko method and the dynamic equations of beam and piezoelectric layer is found in general form. The tip tracking control of the beam using a piezoelectric layer as an actuator based on the Galerkin projection method is presented for the first time. The presented controller has a cascade form which consists of an inner stabilizer control loop and an outer proportional-integral-derivative (PID) control which guarantees the tip tracking control without any error. This configuration is applied to the beam tracking control originally in this paper. A cascade control usually contains two control loops, where the inner loop is a stabilizer with fast dynamics to compensate input disturbances and in this paper it consists of an observer-controller loop, while the outer loop is used to regulate the system or track a desired reference signal (Stephanopoulos, 1984; Murrill, 1988).The controller is designed based on the first mode of the system vibration. The effect of higher modes dynamics in the stability of the presented controller is analyzed. The feedback signal used for stabilizing the dynamics of the beam is based on the tip defection measurement. So an observer is designed to estimate the other state variables needed for the controller design. In many other works done previously for controlling a micro-beam, it is assumed that all state variables of the system are available to be fed back which is an inaccessible assumption. In this paper a real assumption is utilized for a measurement signal and the stability of the inner-loop control in presence of the observer dynamics is investigated.

sec.title: 2. System modeling
sec.p:
The system under consideration is a micro-cantilever Timoshenko beam actuated with a laminated piezoelectric layer on one side as it is shown in Figure 1. The length and width of the beam and piezoelectric layer are illustrated by L and b, also the thickness of beam and piezoelectric layer are denoted by hb and hp respectively in that figure. The piezoelectric layer is actuated in its (3,1) mode. It is assumed that deflection of the beam is small and nonlinear effects of the piezoelectric layer are negligible. In addition, the bending vibration of the beam is only considered. According to Hamilton's principle, there is, (1)∫t0t(δT+δWe*-δWm+δWnc)dt=0. where T is the kinetic energy, We* is the potential co-energy, Wm is the magnetic potential energy, and Wnc is the work of non-conservative forces (Preumont, 2006). For the piezoelectric and beam system, the electric and elastic co-energy can be found by Preumont (2006), (2)d We*=(d We*dV¯)pdV¯p+(d We*dV¯)bdV¯b=(12ETεE+STeE-12STcpS)dV¯p +(-12STcbS)dV¯b, where E is the electric field vector, ε is the permittivity matrix, S is the strain vector in engineering representation, e is the matrix of piezoelectric constants, which relates the stress induced in the piezoelectric material in the unit electric field, when piezoelectric is fully constrained. c is the stress matrix, and V¯ is the total volume of material. The superscripts p and b refer to the piezoelectric and the beam respectively. Figure 1.
A schematic view of the beam with piezoelectric actuator and some geometric parameters.

According to Timoshenko's beam theory, the slope of beam, i.e. vx=∂v/∂x where v is the beam deflection, is considered as a result of two different phenomena. The first one is the angle due to bending, α(x,t), and the second is due to shear deformation β(x,t).
Therefore, (3)vx(x,t)=α(x,t)+β(x,t).

Considering the shear deformation and neglecting longitude elongation of beam, the strain vector can be stated as, (4)S={-zαx,0,0,0,2β,0}T. where z is the distance from neutral axis. The electric field induced by piezoelectric layer in (3,1) mode is, (5)E={0,0,E3(t)}T={0,0,V(t)hp}T, where V(t) is the applied voltage to piezoelectric layer. Substituting (4) and (5) back into (2) and integrating along the beam length yields, (6)We*=∫0L(12ɛ33V2(t)hp+2βe53V(t)-2k'pc55pβ2 -αxe13zmpV(t))bdx -∫0L12c11pαx2Ipdx-∫0L2k'bc55bβ2hbbdx -∫0L12c11bαx2Ibdx, where k' is the shape factor. For the rectangular cross section, the value of shape factor can be found by, (7)k'=10(1+ν)12+11ν where ν is the Poisson ratio (Han et al., 1999). zmp denotes the distance between the middle line of the piezoelectric layer and the neutral axis of the beam. In the Timoshenko theory of beams, both the transversal and rotational kinetic energy of the beam is considered. In other words, the kinetic energy of the beam is, (8)T=12∫0L(ρphpb+ρbhbb)vt2dx +12∫0L(ρpIp+ρbIb)αt2dx.

The work done by damping forces is considered as a non-conservative force. The squeeze film damping is neglected since the beam is assumed to vibrate freely and no solid surface exists above or under the beam. This can reduce the squeeze film effect. Moreover, modeling squeeze film damping adds nonlinearity to the equation of systemand and makes it difficult to control. The authors will consider this effect in their future works, but for now, they assume that the beam has equivalent viscous damping constants c1 and c2 so that, (9)Wnc=-∫0L(c1vtδv+c2αtδα)dx.

Substituting equations (6), (8) and (9) back into (1) and noting that the magnetic potential energy of the system is zero, there will be, (10)∫t0tdt∫0L{((ρphpb+ρbhbb)vt)δvt+(ρpIp+ρbIb)αtδαt -((c11pIp+c11bIb)αx+V(t)e13zmpb)δαx-cvtδv -c2αtδα+((2V(t)e53-4k'pc55phpβ)b -4k'bc55bhbbβ)δβ}dx=0.
Integrating by part and noting that α and β are dependent to each other according to (3), equation (10) can be restated as,

Since equation (11) must be held for all values of δv and δα, the following Euler equations are obtained: (12)ddx(4k'pc55p(vx-α)hpb+4k'bc55bhbb(vx-α)) +(ρphpb+ρbhbb)vtt+c1vt=0, 0<x<L,ddx((c11pIp(x)+c11bIb)αx+V(t)e13zmpb) -(ρpIp+ρbIb)αtt -(2V(t)e53-4k'pc55php(vx-α))b-c2αt +4k'bc55bhbb(vx-α)=0, 0<x<L, ((c11pIp+c11bIb)αx+V(t)e13zmpb)δα=0, x=0,x=L, (2V(t)e53b-(4k'pc55phpb+4k'bc55bhbb)(vx-α))δv=0,x=0,x=L.

Equations (12) describe the lateral vibration of a Timoshenko beam with a laminated piezoelectric actuator. The boundary conditions of a clamped-free cantilever beam require that at the clamped end, i.e. x=0, the variations of deflection and angle due to bending, i.e. δv and δα respectively, be identical to zero. Moreover, these variations at the free end, i.e. x=L are arbitrary. Therefore, for cantilever beams, equation (12) can be restated as (ρphpb+ρbhbb)vtt+c1vt-4(k'pc55phpb+k'bc55bhbb)(vxx-αx)=0, 0<x<L,(ρpIp+ρbIb)αtt+c2αt-(c11pIp+c11bIb)αxx -4(k'pc55phpb+k'bc55bhbb)(vx-α) =-2e53bV(t), 0<x<L,
(13)α(0)=0, αx(L)=-e13zmpbV(t)c11pIp+c11bIb, v(0)=0, vx(L)-α(L)=(e532(k'pc55php+k'bc55bhb)V(t)).

For most of the piezoelectric materials the e53 constant is negligible (Maluf and Williams, 2004). Therefore, its effect can be ignored and equations (13) restated as follows, (14)(ρphpb+ρbhbb)vtt+c1vt-4(k'pc55phpb+k'bc55bhbb) ×(vxx-αx)=0, 0<x<L,(ρpIp+ρbIb)αtt+c2αt-(c11pIp+c11bIb)αxx -4(k'pc55phpb+k'bc55bhbb)(vx-α)=0, 0<x<L, α(0)=0, αx(L)=-e13zmpbV(t)c11pIp+c11bIb, v(0)=0, vx(L)-α(L)=0.

In order to avoid numerical errors during simulation, equation (14) must be stated in dimensionless form. To this end, the following new variables are defined, (15)x=Lx~,ρp=ρbρ~p,e13=e13e~13,L=LL~,t=t~ω1,e35=e13e~35,hpb=L2h~pb~,Ip=L4I~p,c1=ρL2ω1c~1,hbb=L2h~bb~,Ib=L4I~b,c2=ρbLω1c~2,ρb=ρbρ~b,cij=ρbL2ω12c~ij,V=ρbL3ω12e13V~, where the parameters with tilde are dimensionless. Substituting (15) into (14) yields, (16)(ρ~ph~pb~+ρ~bh~bb~)v~t~t~+c~1v~t~-4(k'pc~55ph~pb~+k'bc~55bh~bb~) ×(v~x~x~-αx~)=0, 0<x~<L~,(ρ~pI~p+ρ~bI~b)αt~t~+c~2αt~-(c~11pI~p+c~11bI~b)αx~x~ -4(k'pc~55ph~pb~+k'bc~55bh~bb~)(v~x~-α)=0,<x~<L~, α(0)=0, αx~(L~)=-e~13z~mpb~V~(t~)c~11pI~p+c~11bI~b, v~(0)=0, v~x(L~)-α(L~)=0.
Equation (16) are the dimensionless form of equation (14). From now on, the dimensionless equations will be used and for convenience, the tilde symbol will be neglected.

sec.title: 3. Extracting the state space equations via Galerkin’s method
sec.p: For convenience, Let the equation (16) be restated as, (17)Avtt-B(vxx-αx)+c1vt=0, 0<x<1,Cαtt-Dαxx-B(vx-α)+c2αt=0, 0<x<1,α(0)=0, αx(1)=-k1Du,v(0)=0, vx(1)-α(1)=0. where (18)A=ρphpb+ρbhbb,B=4b(k'pc55php+k'bc55bhb),C=ρpIp+ρbIb,D=c11pIp+c11bIb,k1=e13zmpb,V(t)=u(t).

The effect of piezoelectric voltage, which is called the control signal, can be transferred to main equation using the advantage of the Dirac delta function. It can be shown directly from Hamilton's equation that (17) can be rewritten as, (19)Avtt-B(vxx-αx)+c1vt=0,0<x<1,Cαtt-Dαxx-B(vx-α) +c2αt=k1δ1(x)u(t),0<x<1,α(0)=0, αx(1)=0,v(0)=0, vx(1)-α(1)=0. where δ1(·) is the Dirac delta function applied at x=1. To apply the Galerkin expansion method, the shape functions of the undamped beam are utilized. They are the eigen-functions of the homogenous undamped beam equation, i.e. the solutions of the following equations, (20)BW″-Bφ'+λW=0,Dφ″+BW'-Bφ+CλAφ=0,φ(0)=0,φ'(1)=0,W(0)=0,W'(1)-φ(1)=0, which W(x) is the deflection shape function and φ(x) is the slope shape function.Equations (20) can be restated as, (21)ζ'=Hζ, ( )'=ddx( )ζ(0)=[00c1c2]T where ζ=[ζ1ζ2ζ3ζ4]=[WφW'φ'], and c1 and c2 are two constants, also, (22)H=[00100001-λB0010-(CλA-B)D-BD0], that must satisfy these constraints, (23)ζ4(1)=0,ζ3(1)-ζ2(1)=0, which are related to the second and the forth boundary conditions of equations (20) respectively.The solution of (21) is, (24)ζ(x)=eHxζ(0).
Therefore, (25)ζ(1)=eHζ(0).

Equations (23) have zero trivial solution for c1 and c2, which leads to trivial solution ξ=0 of (21). To find non-trivial solution, two equations of (23) must be dependent. This can occur for specific values of λ, ie. λi, that is related to ith natural frequencies of beam, ωi. In fact, (26)ωi2∝λi.
Having known the values of λi, the ith shape functions Wi(x) and φi(x) can be found by solving (21) and (23).
According to the Galerkin method, the solutions of equation (19) are determined by the following series, (27)v(x,t)=∑i=1∞Wi(x)ηi(t),α(x,t)=∑i=1∞φi(x)ξi(t).

Substituting (27) back into (19) and simplifying it regarding to equation (20) results in, (28)∑i=1∞AWi(x)η··i(t)+c1Wi(x)η·i(t)+(λiWi(x)-Bφi'(x))ηi(t) +Bφi'(x)ξi(t)=0∑i=1∞Cφi(x)ξ··i(t)+c2φi(x)ξ·i(t) +(CλiAφi(x)+BW'i(x))ξi(t)-BW'i(x)ηi(t) =k1u(t)δ1(x).

Multiplying the first equation of (28) by Wj(x) and the second one by φj(x) and integrating over the beam’s length, there follows, (29)∑i=1najiη··i(t)+bη·i(t)+cjiηi(t) +djiξi(t)=0,j=1,…,n,∑i=1nejiξ··i(t)+njiξ·i(t)+gjiξi(t) +hjiηi(t)=mj(t),j=1,…,n, where (30)aji=∫01AWi(x)Wj(x)dx,dji=∫01Bφi'(x)Wj(x)dx,bji=∫01c1Wi(x)Wj(x)dx,eji=∫01Cφi(x)φj(x)dx,cji=∫01(λiWi(x)-Bφi'(x))Wj(x)dx,gji=∫01(CλiAφi(x)+BW'i(x))φj(x)dx,hji=-∫01BW'i(x)φj(x)dx,nji=∫01c2φi(x)φj(x)dx,mj(t)=k1φj(1)u(t).

In equation (29) n is the number of modes considered for simulation. It should be noted that considering all infinite modes is not achievable for numerical simulations, so a finite number of modes is used for simulation. By defining η(t)=[ηi(t)]T, ξ(t)=[ξi(t)]T, W(x)=[Wi(x)]T, ϕ(x)=[φi(x)]T, and using the matrices and vectors defined in (30), equation (29) can be restated as, (31)x·=Ax+Bu, x·=dxdt where (32)A=[0I00-a-1c-a-1b-a-1d0000I-e-1h0-e-1g-e-1n]4n×4n,B=[000k1e-1ϕ(1)]4n×1. where elements of matrices a,b,c,d,e,g,h, and n are defined in (30). Here, the tip tracking of the beam is considered. Also, x=[ηη·ξξ·]T is the state vector. Therefore, the output of the system is defined as, (33)y=Cx, where (34)C=[W(1)T000]1×4n.
As a result, the dynamic equations of system is a well known linear system as follows, (35)x·=Ax+Bu,y=Cx.
Equations (31) to (35) are valid for any number of modes. Although, in simulation, limited number of modes must be considered. Now, the tracking control of the beam’s tip can start.

sec.title: 4. Controller design
sec.p:
The authors’ goal is tracking control of the micro-beam's tip. This is an input-output control problem, where the input is the voltage applied to the piezoelectric layer, and the output is the deflection of the tip. Stability of the system, especially the internal dynamics, is crucial in input-output control problems. To this end, a cascade control system is employed. In a cascade control, the closed loop system contains an inner loop and an outer loop. In this controller, the inner control loop is a stabilizer to maintain the stability, while the outer loop is a PID controller to perform the command set point tracking task. A schematic view of the proposed control system is shown in Figure 2. It is well-known that by establishing the stability of the inner-loop, the PID controller can easily control the output of the system. Figure 2.
Schematic view of a cascade control system.

Although the Galerkin projection method is used to model the beam by its first two modes, in reality, the output of system, which is measured by a sensor, contains all dynamical modes. In other words there are unmodeled dynamics, the existence of which the controller is unaware. To simulate these unmodeled dynamics, in design of inner-loop stabilizer, only the dynamics of the first mode of the beam is used and the dynamics of the higher modes is considered as unmodeled dynamics. It should be stated that higher vibration modes produce an uncontrollable system, so their effects must be regarded as unmodeled dynamics, and should be neglected in stabilizer control design procedure. For simplicity of demonstration, without neglecting the generality, it is assumed that the real dynamics, containing the modeled and unmodeled dynamics, consist of the first and the second vibration modes of the beam, while the model, i.e. the modeled dynamics, are the dynamics of the first mode only. In other words, the system’s real dynamics are assumed to be: (36)[η·1η·2η··1η··2ξ·1ξ·2ξ··1ξ··2]=[0 0 1 0 0 0 0 00 0 0 1 0 0 0 0-c∧11-c∧12-b∧11-b∧12-d∧11-d∧120 0-c∧21-c∧22-b∧21-b∧22-d∧21-d∧220 00 0 0 0 0 0 1 00 0 0 0 0 0 0 1-h∧11-h∧120 0-g∧11-g∧12-n∧11-n∧12-h∧21-h∧220 0-g∧21-g∧22-n∧21-n∧22][η1η2η·1η·2ξ1ξ2ξ·1ξ·2]+[000000e∧1e∧2]u,y=[W1(1)W2(1)0 0 0 0 0 0][η1η2η·1η·2ξ1ξ2ξ·1ξ·2]T.

It is assumed that the controller has no information about the dynamics of the second mode. In fact, the controller is designed based on the modeled dynamics, i.e., (38)∧·x1=A11x∧1+B1u,y∧1=C1x∧1, where, (39)A11=[0100-c11a11-b11a11-d11a1100001-h11e110-g11e11-n11e11],B1=[000k1φ1(1)e11], C1=[W1(1)000],x∧1=[η1η·1ξ1ξ·1]

As a stabilizer control, a full state controller with a state observer is used. The observer is designed to estimate dynamics of the first mode of beam, i.e. η1(t), η·1(t), ξ1(t), ξ·1(t), based on measurement of the tip deflection. In MEMS, it is too difficult to measure the deflection of more than one point. In addition, measuring time derivative of deflection is difficult, and calculating it via a numerical derivative may intensify measurement noises. Therefore, the only feasible available signal is the tip deflection. The observer dynamics is set to be a copy of the known model dynamics of equation (38) plus an estimation error vector, i.e., (40)~·x1=A11x~1+B1u+Ke(y-C1x~1),y=[W(1)W(2)0 0 0 0 0 0] ×[η1η2η·1η·2ξ1ξ2ξ·1ξ·2]T, where x~1 is the estimated state vector and Ke is the observer gain vector. In addition, the controller is designed as a linear full state vector as follow, (41)u=-Kx~1, where K is the control gain vector. Therefore, the closed loop equation of the observer-controller system can be stated as, (42)[∧·x1∧·x1-~·x1]=[A11-B1KB~K0A11-KeC1][x∧1x∧1-x~1] +[0W2(1)η2]

The controller gain K and the observer gain Ke are designed via pole placement techniques to place the closed loop poles of the A11-B1K and A11-KeC1 matrices in the left half of complex plane. It can be achieved only when the pair (A11,B1) is completely controllable and the pair (A11,C1) is completely observable. In this problem, these conditions are satisfied easily for the first mode model of equation (38), but when other higher modes are considered for controller-observer design the controllability and observability conditions are violated. To check the controllability and observability conditions the matrices [B1A11B1A112B1A113B1] and [C1TA11C1TA112C1TA113C1T] must have non-zero determinant, which is satisfied in this problem.
This causes that only the first mode of the system is used for designing the stabilizing controller and other modes is considered as unmodeled dynamics.
In the outer control loop, a PID controller is applied to track the square wave input signal. The PID parameters are tuned by trial and error to improve the response.

In order to avoid excitation of higher modes by controller, a low pass filter is applied to eliminate the high frequency input. In addition, piezoelectric materials have a limit in their electric fields. This limit cause a saturation in voltage applied to piezoelectric actuator.

To consider the effect of higher modes as unmodeled dynamics, the controller, which is designed based on dynamics of the first mode, is applied to control the output of the beam which contains higher modes dynamics as well as the first mode dynamics. In simulation only when the two first modes are utilized, since in real problems, especially in MEMS, the third and higher vibrating modes have a high natural frequency which is far away from the bandwidth of piezoelectric actuator. In addition, as stated before, a low pass filter is applied that filters the high frequency parts of the control signal. Therefore, excitation of the third and higher modes is out of the question.

sec.title: 4.1. Effect of internal dynamics on the stability of inner-loop system
sec.p: Since the input-output controller design is considered, the stability of internal dynamics of the system plays a crucial role in the stability of the whole system when applying the control signal. Global asymptotic stability of the internal dynamics and stability of output assure the global stability of the system. Finding the internal dynamics of a system is somehow complicated. Instead of finding the internal dynamics of a system, its zero dynamics can be studied. Zero dynamics is the internal dynamics of the system when the output holds at zero by the controller. Local asymptotic stability of zero dynamics guarantees the local asymptotic stability of the internal dynamics. In linear systems, all the locally asymptotic stable equilibrium points are globally asymptotic stable. Therefore, the zero dynamics of a system can be studied to ensure the global asymptotic stability of the internal dynamic.

To find the zero dynamics of a system, the value of output must be set and all of its time derivatives equal to zero. For linear system (35), there follows, (43)y(r)=CArx+CAr-1Bu. where (·)(r) shows the r-th derivative with respect to time. If there is: (44)CAiB=0,1≤i<r-1,CAr-1B≠0. the integer r is called the relative degree of the input/output system. Since all the time derivatives of the output must be set to zero, equation (43) yields, (45)u=-CArCAr-1Bx.
Substituting (45) into (35), the zero dynamics of system can be found as, (46)x·=(A-BCArCAr-1B)x.
The system has stable internal dynamic if all the eigenvalues of A-(BCAr)/(CAr-1B) have negative real part.
For the system under consideration with n modes, it can be easy to show that, (47)CA=CAB=CA2B=0, CA3B≠0.

Thus, the relative degree of the system is r=4. Therefore, for the case of modeling the beam with only its first mode, there are no internal dynamics, and it is not necessary to check the stability of internal dynamics. For the case of considering higher modes, the stability of (46) must be checked.

sec.title: 4.2. Effects of higher vibration modes on the stability of inner-loop system
sec.p: As mentioned before, only a limited number of modes is used in dynamic modeling of the beam, and the inner-loop controller-observer is designed based on the first mode dynamics.However, the dynamics of the higher modes can affect the dynamic response and stability of the real system. Therefore, stability analysis is required to comprehend the effects of higher order dynamics.

Let the real dynamics of the system be restated, i.e. equation (35) as, (48)x·1=A11x1+A12x2+B1u,x·2=A21x1+A22x2+B2u,y=C1x1+C2x2, where x1 represents the state variables that are also exist in the modeled dynamics of system, for example the state variables correspond to the first vibrating mode. On the other hand, x2 represents the state variables correspond to unmodeled dynamics. By neglecting x2, dynamics of the model can be simplified as: (49)x∧1=A11x∧1+B1u,y∧1=C1x∧1.

As mentioned in the previous section, it is assumed that the pairs (A11,B1) and (A11,C1) are completely controllable and completely observable, respectively (This is established in this problem). Since all the states are not accessible, a state observer is designed. The dynamic equations of the observer can be found as a copy of model plus an error term representing the difference between measured output, i.e. y, and the estimated output, y∧1. Therefore, the dynamics of the observer can be stated as: (50)~·x1=A11x~1+B1u+Ke(C1x1+C2x2-C1x~1), where the matrix Ke is determined in a way that all the eigenvalues of A11-KeC1 place in the left half of complex plane. The control law is (51)u=-Kx~1e. where K is selected in a way that A11-B1K has negative-real part eigenvalues. As a result, the observer estimation error can be found as, (52)x·1-~·x1=(A11-KeC1)(x1-x~1)+(A12-KeC2)x2,
Let the observer error be denoted by E=x1-x~1. So, the error equation (52) can be restated as, (53)E·=(A11-KeC1)E+(A12-KeC2)x2,

To find the stability condition of system (53), or in other words, the convergence condition of the observer, the following positive definite function is defined as a Lyapunov function: (54)V1=12ETPE. where P is a real positive definite symmetric matrix which is the solution of the following Lyapunov equation: (55)P(A11-KeC1)+(A11-KeC1)TP=-Q. where Q is an arbitrary positive definite symmetric matrix. It should be noted that since all eigenvalues of A11-KeC1 have negative real parts, the above Lyapunov equation has a unique real symmetric positive definite solution, P. Using equation (53), the time derivative of (54) can be calculated as (56)V·1=ET(P(A11-KeC1)+(A11-KeC1)TP)E +2ETP(A12-KeC2)x2.

Referring to (55) and (56), one can deduce that, (57)V·1=-ETQE+2ETP(A12-KeC2)x2≤-λmin(Q)‖E‖2+2‖E‖‖P‖‖A12-KeC2‖‖x2‖, where λmin(Q) referring to the minimum eigenvalue of matrix Q. Therefore, the observation error norm will decrease if the time derivative of the Lyapunov function is negative which leads to the following bound for the observer error: (58)‖E‖≥2‖P‖‖A12-KeC2‖λmin(Q)‖x2‖.

The right hand side expression of the above inequality can be interpreted as the observer error bound, which is proportional to the norm of the unmodeled dynamic states. It means that the observer error decreases until it achieves the abovementioned bound.

Moreover, it is also useful to study the stability of the states related to the known modeled dynamics. To this end, let the following Lyapunov function be defined: (59)V2=12x·1TP~x·1. where P~ is a real positive definite symmetric matrix, and is the unique solution of the Lyapunov equation: (60)P~(A11-B1K)+(A11-B1K)TP~=-Q~. where Q~ is a positive definite real symmetric matrix and all eigenvalues of A11-B1K locate in the left half of complex plane. Therefore, employing the first equation of (48) and (51) leads to (61)V·2=x·1T(P~(A11-B1K)+(A11-B1K)TP~)x1+2x1TP~A12x2+2x1TP~BKE.
Substituting equation (55) into equation (60) results in: (62)V·2=-x·1TQ~x1+2x1TP~A12x2+2x1TP~BKE.

Therefore, (63)V·2≤-λmin(Q~)‖x1‖2+2‖x1‖‖P~‖‖A12‖‖x2‖ +2‖x1‖‖P~‖‖B‖‖K‖‖E‖. where λmin(Q~) referring to the minimum eigenvalue of the matrix Q~. It means that the norm of controlled modeled decreases until it comes to the following bound: (64)‖x1‖≥2‖P~‖‖A12‖‖x2‖+2‖P~‖‖B‖‖K‖‖E‖λmin(Q~).

The right hand side of the above inequality depicts a bound for the x1 state norm. By using equation (58), equation (64) can be stated as a function of ‖x2‖ as follow, (65)‖x1‖≥(2‖P~‖‖A12‖λmin(Q) +4‖P~‖‖P‖‖B‖‖K‖‖A12-KeC2‖)λmin(Q~)λmin(Q)‖x2‖.

It shows that stability of the controlled model depends on the bound of the unmodeled system states. If the unmodeled dynamics is not excited, the modeled controlled dynamics is asymptotically stable. However, if the magnitude of the states of the unmodeled dynamics is not zero but bounded, it can be assured that the inner-loop dynamics is bounded too.

Implementation remark: From equation (65) it can be concluded that, if higher modes dynamics of the system are not excited, the stability of the inner-loop first mode dynamics is guaranteed, and this can be achieved using a low pass filter after the PID control signal as shown in Figure 2.

This result demonstrates how crucial the role of filter is. The applied filter suppresses vibration of the higher modes and reduces the error in the modeled states, however, a careless choose of its cut-off frequency will lead to bad performance of system. It is a well known recommendation that the cut-off frequency must designed in two to five times of the excitation frequency (Gatti and Ferrari, 2003).

sec.title: 5. Simulation results
sec.p:
A silicon dioxide micro-cantilever with a PZT layer laminated on one side of it is considered as a case study. The physical characteristics of the beam and piezoelectric layer can be found in Table 1. Also the geometrical dimensions of the beam and piezoelectric layer are chosen as in Table 2. The first four natural frequencies of beam are reported in Table 3. From this table, it can be seen that as stated before, the third and higher natural frequencies are far from the actuating signal. Also the first four deflection and slope shape modes of beam are shown in Figures 3 and 4 respectively. Figure 3.
Deflection shape modes of a dimensionless Timoshenko beam.
Figure 4.
Slope shape modes of a dimensionless Timoshenko beam.
Table 1.
Material properties of silicon dioxide beam and piezoelectric actuator
Material Density (Kg/m3) Poisson coefficient Young modulus of elasticity (GPa) Piezoelectric constants (10−12 C/N) Relative permitivity
SiO2 2200 0.17 73 - 3.9
PZT 7700 0.31 71 d31 = 175 d33 = 400 d55 = 580 1700
Table 2.
Geometrical dimensions of beam and piezoelectric layer (all in μm)
Beam length Beam thickness Beam width Piezoelectric length Piezoelectric thickness Piezoelectric width
150 10 30 150 10 30
Table 3.
The first four natural frequencies of the beam using both Timoshenko and Euler-Bernoulli models
Euler-Bernoulli beam theory (KHz) Timoshenko beam theory (KHz)
550 547
3450 3314
9659 8833
18908 15951

A saturation limit of 300KV/m is considered for piezoelectric field. For the piezoelectric layer used for this simulation, it leads to 3 V saturation which is equal to 1.24×10-4 in non-dimensional form. The objective is to track a high frequency square wave, which is applicable in high frequency switching. The wave amplitude is 15 nm or in non-dimensional form it is equal to 1×10-4. Finally, the frequency of the square wave is set to be equal to the natural frequency of the first mode, i.e. 547KHz or in non-dimensional form, 1. The inner loop controller, i.e. the stabilizer, is a pole placement control based on dynamics of the first vibrating mode with closed loop poles -1,-1,-1±j. A state observer is used to estimate necessary states for the stabilizer using measured tip deflection with closed loop pole -10,-10,-20±10j. The outer loop controller is a PID controller of the following form, (66)uOC=4.2e+1.1∫e+3.5e·, where e is the tracking error, i.e. (67)e=ydesired-y.

A first order system is defined as a low pass filter with a cut-off frequency about 2750KHz to prevent from excitation of higher modes. The first two modes of the beam are used for performing the simulation while only the first mode is used to design the inner stabilizer control and observer. The reference signal and deflection of the beam is shown in Figure 5. The control effort is depicted in Figure 6. Also, the solution of all the states is shown in Figure 7, which illustrates the stability of the internal dynamics of system and the boundedness of the second mode vibration. Figure 5.
Reference square wave signal and the deflection of the controlled beams tip.
Figure 6.
Controller effort.
Figure 7.
Time histories of the whole states including (a) modeled vibrating mode and (b) unmodeled vibrating mode.

Figure 5 shows that the output can barely track the input signal, which makes the bandwidth of this actuator near 550 KHz. The controller has no difficulties in tracking slower signal (for example 200 KHz which is about 411 of the first natural frequency) as demonstrated in Figure 8. Figure 8.
(a) Response of system to 200 KHz square wave and (b) the designed control signal.

sec.title: Effect of measurement noise
sec.p:
To consider the effect of measurement noise, an unbiased noise signal is added with variance equal to two percent of the amplitude of the command signal. Simulation results are shown in Figure 9. Figure 9.
Effect of measurement noise on (a) response of system and (b) the designed control signal.

sec.title: 6. Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper, the problem of tip tracking control of a micro-cantilever with a piezoelectric layer as an actuator is considered. The beam is modeled by the Timoshenko theory. Dynamic equation of motion of the composite beam is found using the Hamilton principle. State space representation of the beam is found by applying the Galerkin method. A cascade system is used to control the reference signal. This controller contains a stabilizer in its inner loop and a PID controller to track the desired set point. Then, the effects of internal dynamics and higher vibration modes as unmodeled dynamics on the stability of inner-loop controlled system are investigated. Finally, a simulation is performed to examine the effectiveness of the proposed control technique.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.
